_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Additional standards include: American Pipeline Institute, Pipeline Research Council International, Manufacturer's Standardization Society, NACE International, and NFPA 10, 30, 59, & 70
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: Equipment standards in Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 192
_prev_prog_2.MD_OtherType: Tank equipped with visible pressure, volume, and temperature gauges
_prev_prog_2.TR_OtherType: Certified Employee Training Program (CETP) through National Propane Gas Association (NPGA); U.S. Dept. of Transportation; Internal Training; Manufacturer's Training
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: NGL Storage Tank, associated piping, and relief valves
_prev_prog_2.Description:
To prevent accidental releases, the facility trains personnel on the operation of the pressurized natural gas liquids (NGL) Storage Tank and equipment using the National Propane Gas Association's (NPGA) Certified Employee Training Program (CETP), training provided by the manufacturer and the U.S. Department of Transportation, and internal training. There are no employees permanently stationed onsite; however, at least one trained employee will be onsite to supervise tanker truck loading, consistent with their training and written operating procedure. Site conditions and some tank conditions are monitored via telemetry at a centralized Control Center on a 24-hour basis and supplemented with periodic visual inspections by trained personnel. Trained employees will also visit the site at least every month to conduct a "look, listen, and hear" leak check.



Accidental releases are further reduced through technologies integrated into the NGL Storage Tank. These technologies include integrated valve shutoff for all tank piping, over-pressure relief valves, loading rack breakaways, and emergency manual tank shutoff.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This RMP is applicable to a natural gas liquids (NGL) pressurized storage tank.

I.    Facility and Process Description

At this location, a natural gas Mechanical Refrigeration Unit (MRU) chills natural gas from area natural gas wells, delivered via pipeline. The unprocessed natural gas is dehydrated, then chilled in the MRU. In the MRU, lighter materials, (e.g. methane, ethane), are extracted and re-introduced into the natural gas transmission pipeline. The remaining heavier materials, (e.g. propane, pentane), are stored in their liquid form in a pressurized NGL Storage Tank. NGLs are offloaded to a NGL tanker truck for transport to an offsite location for further processing.



The NGLs contain several regulated substances, (e.g. propane, n-butane, pentane, etc.), and the entire NGL mixture meets National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) rating 4 criteria for flammability. The amount of NGLs stored onsite is exceeds the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds. A risk management plan was drafted prior to onsite storage exceeding the threshold quantity.



II.     Accidental Release Prevention Program

To prevent accidental releases, the facility trains personnel on the operation of the pressurized natural gas liquids (NGL) Storage Tank and equipment using the National Propane Gas Association's (NPGA) Certified Employee Training Program (CETP), U.S. Department of Transportation training, manufacturer's training, and internal training. There are no employees permanently stationed onsite; however, at least one trained employee will be onsite to supervise tanker truck loading, consistent with their training and written operating procedure. Site conditions and some tank conditions are monitored 24-hours per day via telemetry at a centralized Control Center and supplemented with periodic visual inspections by trained personnel. Trained personnel conduct a monthly "look, listen, and smell" leak check. Visibly marked emergency shutoff switches with notices are available at the lo

ading area and site exit.



Accidental releases are further reduced through technologies integrated into the NGL Storage Tank. These technologies include: check valves, emergency shutoffs, excess flow valves, over-pressure relief valves, and "Smart Hose" Flow Shutoff Valves on the loading arms.



III.    Five-year Accident History

There have been no accidents at this site since the RMP was drafted and the site became operational. There is no five-year accident history, as the site has not existed for five years.



IV.    Emergency Response Program

In the event of an emergency, the Control Center or any personnel that may be on-site will contact the local fire department to respond to the emergency. The local fire department also may respond based on their own notification via 911 or other emergency communication. The Energy Cooperative will provide technical assistance the local fire department during emergency response as required.



V.    Planned Safety Improvements

The facility was designed to include integrated safety measures. The tank was designed and tested to American Society of Mechanical Engineers standards and American Petroleum Institute standards were used for all associated piping. NFPA 58 and 59 were used to identify requirements to minimize hazards. There were no additional safety measures identified in the most recent process hazards analysis.
